body.p: To understand the basis of the resting membrane potential, we must first investigate the composition of body fluids - intracellular fluid (ICF) and extracellular fluid (ECF). Recall that ICF and ECF are composed of salts like NaCl and KCl that dissociate into their ionic components when placed in aqueous solutions. These ions are the mobile charges in body fluids that move between compartments to generate electrical currents along cell membranes.

image.alt: >NaCl (salt) dissociates in water to form Na+ and Cl- ions
image.caption: NaCl dissociates in water to form ions, mobile charge carriers used to generate electrical currents in living organisms. This work by Cenveo is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 United States (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/us/).

body.p: The ECF and ICF have high concentrations of different salts, which leads to differing concentrations of individual ions in the ECF versus the ICF. Recall from your earlier studies that sodium (Na+), chloride (Cl-), and calcium (Ca2+) are more highly concentrated in the ECF, while potassium (K+) and large anions (An-) are more highly concentrated in the ICF.
